question: Here's an advance copy of Strand Magazine. They've printed 'The Red-Headed League!'
answer: Very impressive.

question: Would you like to see how I treated it?
answer: I can hardly wait. I'm sure I'll find out all sorts of fascinating things about the case that I never knew before.

question: Just what do you mean by that?
answer: Oh, come now, Watson, you must admit that you have a tendency to over-romanticize. You have taken my simple exercises in logic and embellished them, exaggerated them...

question: I deny the accusation.
answer: You have described me as six-foot-four, whereas I am barely six-foot-one.

question: A bit of poetic license.
answer: You have saddled me with this improbable costume, which the public now expects me to wear.

question: That's not my doing. Blame it on the illustrator.
answer: You've made me out to be a violin virtuoso. Here --

question: Oh, really?
answer: The fact is that I could barely hold my own in the pit orchestra of a second-rate music hall.

question: You're much too modest.
answer: You have given the reader the distinct impression that I am a misogynist. Actually, I don't dislike women -- I merely distrust them. The twinkle in the eye and the arsenic in the soup.

question: It's those little touches that make you colorful --
answer: Lurid is more like it. You have painted me as a hopeless dope addict -- just because I occasionally take a five per cent solution of cocaine.

question: A seven per cent solution.
answer: Five per cent. Don't you think I'm aware you've been diluting it behind my back?

question: As a doctor -- and as your friend -- I strongly disapprove of this insidious habit of yours.
answer: My dear friend -- as well as my dear doctor -- I only resort to narcotics when I am suffering from acute boredom -- when there are no interesting cases to engage my mind. Look at this -- an urgent appeal to find six missing midgets.

question: Did you say midgets?
answer: Six of them -- the Tumbling Piccolos -- an acrobatic act with some circus.

question: Disappeared between London and Bristol ... Don't you find that intriguing?
answer: Extremely so. You see, they are not only midgets -- but also anarchists.

question: Anarchists?
answer: By now they have been smuggled to Vienna, dressed as little girls in burgundy pinafores. They are to greet the Czar of all the Russias when he arrives at the railway station. They will be carrying bouquets of flowers, concealed in each bouquet will be a bomb with a lit fuse.

question: You really think so?
answer: Not at all. The circus owner offers me five pounds for my services -- that's not even a pound a midget.

question: Oh. And it sounded so promising --
answer: There are no great crimes anymore, Watson. The criminal class has lost all enterprise and originality. At best they commit some bungling villainy, with a motive so transparent that even a Scotland Yard official can see through it. Mrs. Hudson! MRS. HUDSON!

question: There are no great crimes anymore, Watson. The criminal class has lost all enterprise and originality. At best they commit some bungling villainy, with a motive so transparent that even a Scotland Yard official can see through it. Mrs. Hudson! MRS. HUDSON!
answer: Yes? What is it? What have I done now?

question: There is something missing from my desk.
answer: Missing?

question: Something very crucial. You have been tidying up against my explicit orders.
answer: Oh, I made sure not to disturb anything.

question: Dust, Mrs. Hudson, is an essential part of my filing system. By the thickness of it, I can date any document immediately.
answer: Some of the dust was this thick.

question: That would be March, 1883.
answer: How can you stand this? Why don't you let me air the room out?

question: How can you stand this? Why don't you let me air the room out?
answer: Please, Mrs. Hudson -- he's working on a definitive study of tobacco ash.

question: I'm sure there's a crying need for that.
answer: In our endeavors, it is sometimes vital to distinguish between, say, the ashes of a Macedonian cigarette and a Jamaican cigar. Sor far he has classified 140 different kinds of ashes.

question: All of which will end up on my rug.
answer: That'll be enough, Mrs. Hudson.

question: She's right. I am suffocating.
answer: Let me open a window.

question: Not from lack of air -- from lack of activity. Sitting here week after week -- blowing smoke rings -- staring through a microscope -- there's no challenge in that.
answer: Personally, I consider it a major contribution to scientific criminology...

question: How I envy you your mind, Watson.
answer: You do?

question: It's placid, imperturbable, prosaic. But my mind rebels against stagnation. It's like a racing engine, tearing itself to pieces because it's not connected up with the work for which it was built.
answer: Holmes -- Holmes, where is your self-control?

question: Fair question.
answer: Aren't you ashamed of yourself?

question: I made you some tea and cress sandwiches.
answer: Mrs. Hudson, I want you to pack my bags.

question: Are you going away for the weekend?
answer: And beyond. I'm moving out.

question: I'm just as surprised as you are.
answer: You heard me, Mrs. Hudson. And let's not waste any time.

question: May I be so bold as to ask where you'er going?
answer: I don't know yet. But I intend to resume my practice. I am, after all, a doctor. And quite a competent one, if I say so as shouldn't.

question: You'll find it very dull -- snipping out tonsils and flushing out kidneys -- If you're looking for your medical bag, you hid it under the Moorish table. Which shows a little more imagination than last time -- when it was under your bed.
answer: I will, of course, continue to pay my half of the rent until you find someone to share these rooms with you.

question: Where am I going to find anyone who will put up with my rather eccentric habits?
answer: Here's a fresh needle -- and here's my farewell present to you. If you want to destroy yourself, go right ahead. But I won't sit by and watch you doing it.

question: It's so sad. You and Mr. Holmes -- after all these years --
answer: Please, Mrs. Hudson -- none of that.

question: I'll wash this and send it on to you.
answer: I'll be at Brown's Hotel.

question: I know how it feels -- I once went through a divorce myself.
answer: Actually, I'm rather looking forward to it. Leading a normal life again. Regular office hours -- nine to three -- and if occasionally there's an emergency call in the middle of the night, I know it's going be appendicitis and not an ax murder. Let Holmes go mucking about in the fog and the sleet, looking for a bloodstained collar-button out on the moors, with some demented hound snapping at his behind --

question: Mr. Holmes...
answer: Please, Mrs. Hudson. You're in my line of fire.

question: How many times have I told you I will not tolerate pistol practice on my premises? I should have evicted you when you shot them holes in my wall.
answer: Merely celebrating Her Majesty's Golden Jubilee.

question: You heard him.
answer: Thank you, Holmes. I know how difficult it must've been for you --

question: Not really. It was simple choice between a bad habit and a good companion.
answer: You've made me very happy.

question: I've often been accused of being cold and unemotional. I admit to it. And yet, in my cold, unemotional way, I'm very fond of you, Watson.
answer: I know that. But one likes to hear these things occasionally. Look at this. Covered with that nasty stuff. I'd better dry it off.

question: I'll do it.
answer: For a moment, I was worried that you were going to let me walk out -- that you weren't even going to try to stop me.

question: Why are you being so stubborn, Holmes? Why won't you go? It's the final performance of the Imperial Russian Ballet -- the house has been sold out for months -- -- seats are going for a guinea apiece --
answer: That's precisely it. Why should someone send up two free tickets? Anonymously, at that.

question: Whoever sent them must be in great distress. The note says --
answer: I suspect it's some sort of plot.

question: You mean somebody wants to lure us into a trap...?
answer: Somebody wants to kill me.

question: Kill you?
answer: That's right. It's a plot to bore me to death. I detest ballet.

question: But this isn't just any ballet. It's Swan Lake. You know, of course, Holmes -- that swan isn't really a swan -- it's an enchanted princess.
answer: H'mmmm.

question: Very strong arches, I must admit.
answer: They say twelve men have died for her.

question: Really.
answer: Six committed suicide, four were killed in duels, and one fell out of the gallery in the Vienna Opera House.

question: That's only eleven.
answer: The man who fell from the gallery landed on top of another man in the orchestra.

question: Mister Holmes?
answer: Yes.

question: I am Nicolai Rogozhin, director-general of the Imperial Russian Ballet. So glad you accept invitation.
answer: This is Dr. Watson.

question: Any insanity in your family? Diabetes? Asthma?
answer: Would you mind telling me what this is all about?

question: Certainly. Madame Petrova, she has problem.
answer: Could you be more specific?

question: There you are, Mr. Holmes. Madame is expecting you in her dressing room. Dr. Watson, you will amuse yourself meanwhile -- we have vodka, caviar, girls.
answer: No, thank you.

question: No girls?
answer: No caviar. Makes me break out in hives.

question: Dievushki. Siude, siuda, dievushki. Posnakomtes s docktorum Watsonom.
answer: Any of you girls understand English? Not one single word? In that case, I don't mind telling you that you all have lovely po-pos.

question: Otchen rada.
answer: Madame.

question: Vi menshe rostom chem ja ozhidala.
answer: Madame says you are shorter than she thought. I didn't mean to be.

question: Here -- take it. Madame says it is yours.
answer: Mine?

question: For services you will render.
answer: My fees as a detective are not exactly trifling -- but a Stradivarius -- you're not serious.

question: All right. I will pour vodka and explain. Mr. Holmes, what you have seen tonight is last and positively final performance of Madame Petrova. She is retiring.
answer: What a shame.

question: She has been dancing since she was three years old. And after all, she is now thirty-eight.
answer: I must say she doesn't look thirty-eight.

question: That is because she is forty-nine. So Madame has decided to leave ballet and spend life bringing up her child.
answer: How admirable.

question: Problem now is to find father.
answer: Oh? Is he missing?

question: Correct.
answer: And that's why you called me in?

question: Also correct. We must have father, because without father, how can there be child?
answer: I see. The whole thing is still in the planning stage --

question: Za zdorovie.
answer: Za zdrovie. What's in it?

question: What does it taste like?
answer: Red pepper.

question: I beg your pardon?
answer: Madame wants to know how soon you can be ready.

question: Ready?
answer: To leave for Venice. All arrangements have been made. You will spend one week there with Madame...

question: Well, this is all very flattering. But surely there are other me -- better men --
answer: To tell you truth, you were not first choice. We considered Russian writer, Tolstoi --

question: That's more like it. The man's a genius.
answer: Too old... Then we considered the philosopher, Nietzsche --

question: Absolutely first-rate mind...
answer: Too German... And we considered Tschaikowski --

question: Oh, you couldn't go wrong with Tschaikowski --
answer: We could -- and we did. It was catastrophe.

question: Why?
answer: You don't know? Because Tschaikowski -- how shall put it? Women not his glass of tea.

question: Madame is very happy with final choice.
answer: Madame mustn't be too hasty. She must remember I'm an Englishman.

question: So?
answer: You know what they say about us. If there's one thing more deplorable than our cooking, it's our love-making. We are not exactly the most romantic of people --

question: Perfect. We don't want sentimental idiots -- falling in love, committing suicide. One week in Venice -- she goes back to St. Petersburg with baby -- you go back to London with fiddle.
answer: An equitable arrangement. About my medical history -- when you asked me -- I neglected to mention a small detail. There is hemophilia in my family. We're all bleeders.

question: Madame says you talk too much. You find her attractive or no?
answer: Excuse me. What does prokanzik mean?

question: It means 'You little devil.'
answer: It does? I am? Thank you.

question: I repeat question. You find Madame attractive or no?
answer: Oh, I find her most attractive -- for a woman, that is.

question: Then no problem.
answer: Maybe a slight one. You see, I am not a free man.

question: Not free? You are a bachelor.
answer: A bachelor -- living with another bachelor -- for the last five years. Five very happy years.

question: What is it you are trying to tell me?
answer: I hoped I could avoid the subject. But some of us -- through a cruel caprice of Mother Nature --

question: Get to point.
answer: The point is that Tschaikowski is not an isolated case.

question: You mean, you and Dr. Watson -- ? He is your glass of tea?
answer: If you want to be picturesque about it.

question: Home? Not a chance. Not the slightest -- not the remotest chance. Toodle-ooo. Hold on! Just a moment! What's going on? What happened to the girls?
answer: Why? Do you not prefer it this way?

question: What way?
answer: You don't have to pretend. Mr. Holmes told us everything -- about you and him --

question: About me and him?
answer: Come now, no need to be bashful. We are not bourgeois. Maybe with doctors and detectives is unusual -- but in ballet, is very usual.

question: What is?
answer: Caprice of Mother Nature. Look at Pavel and Mischa and Boris and Dmitri -- -- And Ilya and Sergei -- Sergei -- half and half.

question: Holmes! Holmes! There you are, you wretch! You rotter! You blackguard! Of all the vile, unspeakable fabrications. What do you have to say for yourself? Don't just sit there -- speak up, man! Holmes...? Are you all right, Holmes?
answer: From the sound of your footsteps, I gathered that you were not in a particularly amiable mood.

question: How could you do a dastardly thing like that to me? What the deuce were you thinking of?
answer: Watson, you have my most abject apologies. But have you ever been cornered by a madwoman? It seemed like the only way to get out of it without hurting her feelings.

question: What about my feelings? And my reputation? Do you realize the gravity of what you have done? The possible repercussions?
answer: So there'll be a little gossip about you in St. Petersburg...

question: These things spread like wildfire. I can just hear those malicious whispers behind my back. I'll never be able to show my face in polite society...
answer: Watson, you're running amok.

question: Dishonored, disgraced, ostracized. What am I to do?
answer: Well, for one thing, I'd get rid of that flower.

question: You may think this is funny, but we're both in the same boat. We must take desperate measures. We must stop this talk... Maybe if we got married...
answer: Then they'd really talk...

question: Obviously, we cannot continue to live under the same roof. We must move apart.
answer: Of course, we can still see each other clandestinely -- on remote benches in Hyde Park, and in the waiting rooms of suburban railway stations --

question: The whole thing is ridiculous. We have nothing to hide.
answer: That's what I've been trying to tell you.

question: Let somebody start a rumor -- just one ugly word -- and we'll sue them for slander.
answer: Nobody would dare. After all, you have an enviable record with the fair sex.

question: Damn right. I can get women from three continents to testify for me. And you can get women to vouch for you, too -- can't you, Holmes? Can you, Holmes?
answer: Good night, Watson.

question: Holmes, let me ask you a question -- I hope I'm not being presumptuous -- but there have been women in your life?
answer: The answer is yes. You're being presumptuous. Good night.

question: Were you expecting someone?
answer: Not at this hour.

question: Maybe Mrs. Hudson is entertaining.
answer: I never found her so.

question: For what?
answer: For the fare, guv'nor. The young lady doesn't have any money.

question: What young lady?
answer: This one.

question: Look at this -- she's had a nasty blow on the head. No. The blood has already coagulated. So it would appear that she was the victim of a deliberate attack... Get my bag, will you?
answer: Who are you?

question: I'm Dr. Watson -- and this is Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Do the names mean anything to you?
answer: No.

question: Think.
answer: I'm trying.

question: Vous etes Suisse?
answer: Non.

question: Alors, vous etes Belge.
answer: Je suis pas sure.

question: Vous etes Belge -- de Bruxelles!
answer: Bruxelles? Oui... Je pense que oui.

question: If you don't mind. Your name is Gabrielle, is that right? Gabrielle?
answer: I don't know.

question: And your husband's name is Emile?
answer: Emile...

question: Where is he? What are you doing in London?
answer: I don't know.

question: When did you arrive from Brussels? Where are you staying?
answer: I don't know.

question: I'd better mix her a sleeping potion.
answer: Watson, I think we should arrange to have her removed to a hospital.

question: Under no circumstances.
answer: She should have medical attention.

question: She can get that from me. But more importantly, she must be protected -- there has already been one attempt on her life.
answer: This temporary amnesia -- how temporary is it?

question: It depends on the extent of the injury. It's like veils shrouding her memory. It could clear up in a few days -- or a few weeks.
answer: Watson, this is a very small flat -- we don't want to clutter it up with women...

question: Holmes, we've never had a case like this. A woman comes to us with a problem -- we don't know who the woman is -- and we don't know what the problem is. Don't you find that challenging?
answer: Quite. But we can't afford to wait for those veils to lift -- we must break through them as quickly as possible.

question: You really feel it's that urgent?
answer: I do. The sooner we solve the case, the sooner we can get rid of her.

question: Emile? Emile? Emile? Is that you, Emile?
answer: Yes, Gabrielle.

question: Ah, Emile. I thought I'd never find you. Hold me. Hold me tight. It's been such a long time. So many nights. You know what I did before I left Brussels?
answer: What?

question: I hope you won't be angry with me. I bought myself an expensive negligee.
answer: Did you?

question: A pink negligee with maribou feathers. Don't you think that's a foolish thing for a married woman? Come.
answer: Where is the negligee?

question: In my luggage... Come here.
answer: And where is your luggage?

question: Dr. Watson! Your porridge is getting lumpy. Hadn't you better get up?
answer: I would like to very much. But -- Mrs. Hudson, would you mind planting your knee in the small of my back?

question: Yes, I would.
answer: Please! I'm in excruciating pain. A bit higher -- just below my seventh vertebra -- That's good. Put your arms under mine -- fold them behind my neck -- Bless you. That damn couch. You'd better see if our patient is awake.

question: Dr. Watson. She's gone.
answer: Gone? Holmes! Holmes! She's gone!

question: You can't really blame her -- I mean, the way it looks -- if I didn't know you better, I might suspect you'd taken advantage of the young lady.
answer: As a matter of fact, I did take advantage of her... Would you hand me the butter- knife, please?

question: Of course. You did what?
answer: Thank you.

question: Holmes, this is reprehensible! Where are your professional ethics? Have you no sense of decency, no shame --
answer: None whatsoever. If you must know, I found her body quite rewarding.

question: You cad!
answer: Especially the palm of her right hand.

question: I'd rather not hear about it!
answer: Very well. Then I won't bother to tell you how I traced her suitcase.

question: That's her suitcase?
answer: Remember that piece of soggy cardboard with our address on it? It was a luggage ticket -- the number rubbed off on her hand. And since she must have arrived from Brussels by the boat train, I concluded that she had checked her belongings at Victoria Station.

question: By Jove! If you're right, we should find a clue to her identity.
answer: Or at least a pink negligee with maribou feathers. Voila!

question: Let's see - what else is in here?
answer: Now we're getting somewhere.

question: Who do you suppose this is?
answer: Come in, Madame Valladon. You are Gabrielle Valladon.

question: Come in, Madame Valladon. You are Gabrielle Valladon.
answer: Yes.

question: And this is your husband, Emile Valladon?
answer: Yes.

question: Sorry to have ransacked your valise. But since you came to us for help --
answer: Where am I?

question: It's all so confusing.
answer: Let's try to sort it out. You came to London looking for your husband...

question: Yes. He's a mining engineer. We were married five years ago, in the Congo.
answer: Where your husband was working in a copper mine.

question: How did you know?
answer: Your wedding ring -- it's made of copper.

question: Maybe. Here comes our letter. Now we are faced with the most nerve- wracking part of the detective's job -- doing nothing.
answer: Mr. Holmes --

question: Yes?
answer: I don't know how I'm going to pay you for all this. The purse with my money is somewhere at the bottom of the Thames.

question: It could be worse. You could be at the bottom of the Thames -- much to your discomfort -- and much to my chagrin.
answer: I don't understand how anybody picks up letters here. No footprints -- just tracks. What does it mean?

question: I would surmise somebody is using ice- skates -- if it weren't for a conspicuous absence of ice.
answer: What do we do now?

question: It certainly would simplify things, wouldn't it?
answer: Maildrops and canaries and wheelchairs... And what was all that about Jonah? And what do you suppose they're doing up there? And where is up there?

question: My guess would be Scotland. Inverness, to be more precise.
answer: Inverness?

question: Didn't you notice the paper at the bottom of their cage? The Inverness Courier.
answer: Mr. Holmes! This letter --

question: What about it?
answer: It's addressed to you.

question: Nevertheless -- My Dear Sherlock
Either your watch is wrong, or Mycroft has miscalculated. And knowing Mycroft, I suggest you reset your watch.
answer: I don't mind telling you I'm a bit apprehensive about this.

question: I'm rather curious myself as to what is going on in that Machiavellian mind of his.
answer: I don't mean Mycroft, I mean Madame Valladon.

question: Mmmm. Superb. How old did you say it was?
answer: 1814. One year before Waterloo.

question: One year before Waterloo? Think of that.
answer: You do know where Waterloo is, don't you, Doctor?

question: Belgium, isn't it?
answer: Quite. And speaking of Belgium, it has come to my attention that you are interested in the whereabouts of a certain engineer.

question: Quite. And speaking of Belgium, it has come to my attention that you are interested in the whereabouts of a certain engineer.
answer: Yes, I am.

question: Well, I can save you a lot of trouble.
answer: I'd be grateful for any suggestion --

question: My suggestion is that you pursue it no further.
answer: Any particular reason?

question: The Diogenes Club, of course.
answer: I didn't say that.

question: I have always suspected that there was some underground connection between this stodgy and seemingly calcified establishment and the Foreign Office in Whitehall.
answer: That's neither here nor there.

question: It seems to me that The Diogenes Club is here, there and everywhere. When there are rumblings of revolt in the Sudan, an expedition subsidized by your club conveniently shows up to study the source of the Nile. When there is trouble along the Indian frontier, some of your fellow members pop up in the Himalayas, alledgedly looking for the Abominable Snowman.
answer: What a fertile imagination my brother has. At the age of five, by carefully observing a neighbor's house, he deduced that babies were brought not by the stork, but by the mid-wife in her satchel.

question: Yes, Wiggins? Tell them that the three boxes go to Glennahurich, and the red runner goes to the castle.
answer: Why don't you crumple it up and swallow it -- to make sure.

question: My dear Sherlock, there are certain affairs that do not come within the province of the private detective. They have to be dealt with on an altogether different level.
answer: In other words, you want me to stay within my limits.

question: I do indeed.
answer: Speaking of limits, what exactly is Jonah Limited?

question: Sherlock, when I said drop this case, it was not merely a suggestion -- it was an order!
answer: By whose authority?

question: You will be gentle, won't you, when you tell her you're dropping the case?
answer: Watson, what does the word Glennahurich suggest to you?

question: Absolutely nothing.
answer: It's Scottish.

question: Is it?
answer: And like all Scottish names, it's really a word picture. Glen means valley, na means of the, and Hurich, if memory serves me, means yew tree.

question: You're just trying to impress me.
answer: So the three boxes go to the Valley of the Yew Tree.

question: And I'll be in Scotland before ye... You are dropping the case, aren't you, Holmes?
answer: Open the door. Don't shoot, Mrs. Hudson -- you're liable to lose two excellent tenants.

question: Any news? Did you find out anything?
answer: Let's just say I know what the next step will be.

question: Yes?
answer: I want you to pack your things.

question: The boat-train?
answer: Well, that's better.

question: You're sending me back to Brussels? Is that it?
answer: Madame Valladon, you must understand...

question: I came here to find my husband -- you were going to help me --
answer: Yes, my dear. But circumstances have changed --

question: The great detective! Well, maybe this case is too small for you --
answer: On the contrary. It's being handled at a much higher level --

question: But what game? Are you really that interested in the Belgian engineer? Or the wife of the Belgian engineer?
answer: You don't like me very much, do you?

question: Nothing of the sort. Quite the opposite... But there's more to this case than meets the eye -- Looking for something?
answer: My other glove.

question: Let me help you. Here it is.
answer: Thank you.

question: All right. You can look now.
answer: Am I embarrassing you, Mr. Holmes?

question: Not at all. Would it surprise you if I told you I once spent the night with 121 women?
answer: Oh?

question: Women are never to be trusted entirely -- not the best of them.
answer: What did you say?

question: I didn't say it -- you did. According to Dr. Watson.
answer: Oh.

question: He gave me some back issues of Strand Magazine.
answer: The good doctor is constantly putting words into my mouth.

question: Then you deny it?
answer: Not at all. I am not a whole-hearted admirer of womankind.

question: I'm not very fond of them myself.
answer: The most affectionate woman I ever knew was a murderess.

question: Oh?
answer: It was one of those passionate affairs -- at odd hours -- right in my laboratory. And all the time, behind my back, she was stealing cyanide to sprinkle on her husband's steak and kidney pie.

question: You mustn't judge all women by --
answer: Of course not. Only the ones I was involved with. And I don't just mean professionally -- kleptomaniacs, nymphomaniacs, pyromaniacs. Take my fiancee, for instance --

question: Your fiancee?
answer: She was the daughter of my violin teacher -- we were engaged to be married -- the invitations were out, I was being fitted for a tail-coat -- and twenty-four hours before the wedding, she died of influenza.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: It just proves my contention that women are unreliable and not to be trusted. Good night, Mrs. Ashdown.

question: How do you get to Glennahurich? How far is it?
answer: You know -- a valley -- with a yew tree... ? Well, if it's got a view, it might be a nice place for a picnic.

question: Why not?
answer: The three boxes. Is that it, Holmes?

question: Sad -- and rather odd. There are no flowers -- and no mourners. Morning.
answer: Morning.

question: Working you hard, Dad?
answer: Not really. This is healthy country. Sometimes you sit around for weeks with nothing to do. Then you get three in one day.

question: What happened?
answer: An accident. Aye. Father and two sons, they say -- they were found floating in the loch.

question: Local people?
answer: No. Nobody around here knows them. The story is that their boat capsized in a swell -- but I don't believe it.

question: What do you believe?
answer: You may think I'm an old fool or an old drunk -- but I've living around Loch Ness all my life...

question: You may think I'm an old fool or an old drunk -- but I've living around Loch Ness all my life...
answer: Are you trying to tell us it was the monster?

question: Damn right. MacLarnin saw the kids' faces when they were pulled out of the water -- looked like old men -- must've died of fright.
answer: Incredible.

question: It would appear not.
answer: However, there still remains the clue of the castle and the red runner -- wherever it may be. If they're unidentified graves, why are those boys bringing flowers?

question: Because it's their brothers who have just been buried.
answer: Their brothers?

question: And they're not boys. They're as tall as they'll ever grow. Hand me some pebbles, will you?
answer: Pebbles.

question: Midgets.
answer: Boys with the faces of old men...

question: I still don't see --
answer: Would it help if I told you they were acrobats?

question: Not at all.
answer: Do you remember a tumbling act -- six brothers -- missing from the circus?

question: Oh, yes -- that case you turned down -- I completely forgot.
answer: Some of us are cursed with memories like flypaper. And stuck there is a staggering of miscellaneous date, mostly useless.

question: Quite. The question now is -- who's in the third grave?
answer: Holmes! She's fainted.

question: Hand me that lantern.
answer: It is Valladon, isn't it?

question: This way, please. I will show you to your room.
answer: I suppose you're putting me in the basement.

question: No, your room is in the attic.
answer: Good.

question: May I have your wedding ring, please? Just as I thought. There is a distinct difference in color between your ring and your husband's. Which leads me to believe that the cause of death was not drowning... I wish you would stop that. Stop it!
answer: I'm sorry.

question: I know it's not easy. But you must remember that we're that nice couple from London, on Holiday in the Highlands.
answer: I'll try.

question: That's much better.
answer: Thank you.

question: Holmes! I saw it! I saw it from the attic! It's out there in the lake!
answer: You saw what?

question: The telescope. Where's the telescope?
answer: What did you see?

question: The monster!
answer: The monster?

question: There it is! There it is! Look for yourself. See it? See it?
answer: I see nothing.

question: Nothing? It's gone.
answer: Gone? Maybe it was never there.

question: I swear to you -- I saw it -- clear as anything --
answer: Watson, as you so succinctly put it, we are living in the Nineteenth Century --

question: There is only one substance that can turn a copper ring green and bleach the color out of canaries -- chlorine gas.
answer: That may be. But the fact remains that I saw something out there.

question: A figment of your imagination. Now let us be logical. The only concrete lead we have is the reference to the castle -- The question is, which castle?
answer: You call yourself logical? You're the least logical man I know.

question: Am I?
answer: How can you say it's a figment of my imagination, when for years you've been saying I have no imagination whatsoever! We have so far investigated eight drafty castles -- had our bicycles attacked by sheep and our ears assaulted by bagpipes -- and we are exactly where we started.

question: When rebuffed at the front door, one's only choice is to try the tradesmen's entrance.
answer: Sorry. No visitors allowed.

question: Are you the guide here?
answer: Yes. The castle is closed to the public while work is going on.

question: What are they doing?
answer: It's being restored by the Society for the Preservation of Scottish Monuments.

question: Too bad. I particularly wanted my wife to see Urquhart Castle. The tower is one of the most interesting examples of -- about 1400, wasn't it?
answer: That's right.

question: Let me see -- was it built under James the Second or James the Third?
answer: The Thrid... If you come back next year, we'll be all done here, and I'll be glad to show you around.

question: To a graduate chemist it makes a great deal of sense. Sulphuric acid, when exposed to salt-water, produces chlorine gas. Would you mind clasping your hands, Watson?
answer: Like this?

question: A little lower... Thank you. That tower may be more interesting than I thought -- and not just architecturally.
answer: Holmes, I have a feeling we're redundant here. We have now observed the castle from the front, from the back, from the side, from land, from water... what now? Are you planning to spend the night out here?

question: If necessary.
answer: You're going to catch your death of cold. Wouldn't it be ironic if Holmes' last case were a case of pneumonia? Sorry.

question: Holmes!
answer: Quick, Watson. After it!

question: Holmes, what are we doing? We should be going away from it.
answer: Keep rowing, dammit! We've lost it.

question: At least you admit there's an it, not just a figment of my imagination.
answer: Quiet. Do you have your stethoscope with you?

question: Never without it. What is it?
answer: I can hear something... It's getting closer -- closer -- Are you all right?

question: I don't think it will. Look!
answer: What strange goings-on.

question: Not really. My guess is that the monster, after a hard day's work, has returned home for his supper.
answer: Yes, I know. But would you believe that you can't borrow a decent pair of trousers in this place? Would you like to confide in us? Whenever he starts whistling, I know he's getting close to a solution.

question: It's nothing new, actually. We've come across this situation before.
answer: We have? Where?

question: At the ballet.
answer: Ballet?

question: There's a lake -- and there's a castle -- and there's a swan that isn't really a swan -- or, in this case, a monster that isn't really a monster --
answer: Then what is it?

question: Come in.
answer: Mr. Ashdown, I have a bottle of champagne for you.

question: A bottle of champagne? I didn't order it.
answer: No, indeed. You are to deliver it. These are my instructions.

question: Instructions from whom? Deliver it where?
answer: I wouldn't know, sir. But there's a carriage waiting for you downstairs.

question: Are you sure you have the right Mr. Ashdown?
answer: Quite sure, Mr. Holmes.

question: Who's minding the castle?
answer: You'd better get on. It's late.

question: Where are we going? Some sort of party?
answer: You won't be disappointed in the guest list.

question: Who's the host?
answer: Jonah.

question: Mr. Ashdown, I presume.
answer: The red runner, I presume.

question: It's not for you. McKeller. May I have the champagne, please?
answer: 1886 -- not a very good vintage, is it?

question: Mediocre. But then again, it's not for drinking. Tie it up, will you? In here.
answer: Interesting -- and educational.

question: Despite my most emphatic warning, you persisted in meddling. It would have served you right if you'd all drowned.
answer: Sorry to be so unobliging. E. Valladon... H'mm.

question: I imagine this belongs to the pretty lady, and this belongs to your valet... We found them floating in the lake.
answer: Speaking about things floating in the lake --

question: How much do you know -- or think you know?
answer: I think you're testing some sort of underwater craft -- camouflauged to mislead the gullible. I think it's an experimental model, operated by a crew of midgets. I think it is powered by sulphuric acid batteries, and uses canaries to detect escaping gas... Altogether a strange contraption.

question: Not quite that unique. Right now, four countries are trying to develop what we call a submersible. But none of them could solve the critical problem -- how to stay submerged long enough to make it effective.
answer: What does the Good Book say? "And Jonah lived in the belly of that fish for three days and three nights."

question: That was our goal. And thanks to Valladon's air-pump, we got a jump on the rest of them. It's a highly complex system of filtration -- so we had a series of trials --
answer: And at least one error.

question: During a test run in Moray Firth, pressure caused a leak in the hull. Sea water mixed with the acid in the batteries to produce chlorine gas. Before they could reach the surface, Valladon and the crew were dead.
answer: So you had them buried in unmarked graves, to preserve your secret.

question: It was essential to keep the information from your client.
answer: You went to all those lengths to prevent Madame Valladon from fiding her husband?

question: Your client isn't Madame Valladon -- it's the Imperial German Government. They were after the Belgian engineer -- or rather, his invention. They knew he was employed by us, but they couldn't find out where -- so they enlisted the best brain in England to help them. You, my dear brother, have been working for the Wilhelmstrasse.
answer: And Madame Valladon -- what part did she play in all this?

question: Madame Valladon is dead.
answer: Dead?

question: The Germans disposed of her three weeks ago, in Brussels. This is Gabrielle Valladon. The woman who was brought to your house in the middle of the night -- apparently fished out of the Thames -- and apparently suffering from amnesia -- is, in fact, Ilse von Hoffmanstal, one of their most skillful agents. Am I going too fast for one of the "best brains in England?"
answer: Go on.

question: They planted her on you quite neatly, I must admit, so that you could lead them to their objective, the air pump. Very much like using a hog to find truffles. And now perhaps you'd care to join me. I am expecting a certain royal personage from Balmoral. Your Majesty. I trust you had a pleasant journey, Ma'am.
answer: It was long and it was tedious. And it had better be worth our while, Mr. Holmes.

question: I can assure you, Ma'am, it will be.
answer: Now what is this curious ship we are supposed to christen?

question: We call it a submersible, Ma'am. It travels under water.
answer: Under water? What a fantastic idea.

question: Ma'am, may present some of the scientists who were responsible for this achievement. J.W. Ferguson, naval architect -- Professor Simpson, our leading expert on hydraulics -- W.W. Prescott, co-inventor of the revolving periscope -- And this is Sir Arthur Grisby, our authority on maritime ballistics --
answer: We don't claim to understand any of this. But England is proud of you, gentlemen. To think that man can now observe fish in their native habitat --

question: Well, not exactly, Ma'am --
answer: -- and underwater plants and coral reefs -- Young man -- what was your contribution to this project?

question: Ah, yes. Sherlock Holmes. We have been following your exploits with great interest.
answer: Thank you, Ma'am.

question: Are you engaged in one of your fascinating cases at the moment?
answer: In a manner of speaking, Ma'am.

question: When can we expect to read Dr. Watson's account of the case?
answer: I hope never, Ma'am. It has not been one of my more successful endeavors.

question: Ah, the ceremonies are about to begin. Now where is this underwater ship of yours?
answer: In the dungeon, Ma'am.

question: The dungeon? What a peculiar place to keep it. Well, let us get on with it, gentlemen.
answer: There she, Ma'am. Her Majesty's Ship Jonah.

question: And what, may we ask, is the purpose of that hideous gargoyle?
answer: It's merely a decoy, Ma'am.

question: Oh. To frighten away the sharks, we imagine.
answer: Something of the sort... The crew will now demonstrate the workings of the submersible.

question: Aren't they rather small for sailors?
answer: They are. But because of the size of the craft, the Navy made an exception.

question: They should make it a rule. It's quite fatiguing to pin on all those medals while standing on our toes.
answer: This is the main engine, which propels it under water at the rate of two knots -- the stabilizing mechanism -- the multi- stage compressor -- the ballast tank trimmer -- the air-pump which filters and recirculates the air --

question: How charming.
answer: The air pump, Ma'am?

question: The canaries. Must make the crew feel at home.
answer: Yes, Ma'am. These are the levers for firing the torpedoes, which are accurate up to as much as 120 feet -- the periscope for scanning the surface of the water --

question: But where is the glass bottom?
answer: The what, Ma'am?

question: -- and the plants and the corals --
answer: That's not quite the idea, Ma'am. H.M.S. Jonah is being commissioned as a warship.

question: A warship? Stop that noise. Stop it!
answer: Ma'am, if I may explain --

question: You had better.
answer: The Admiralty regards this craft as the ultimate weapon in naval warfare. It can seek out enemy ships and destroy them -- with these torpedoes -- while remaining completely invisible.

question: You mean in can fire at other vessels while under water?
answer: Yes, Ma'am.

question: Without any warning?
answer: That is correct, Ma'am.

question: And without showing her colors?
answer: Indeed, Ma'am.

question: Mr. Holmes, we are not amused. It is unsportsmanlike, it is un-English, and it is in very poor taste. We will have none of it!
answer: I beg your pardon, Ma'am?

question: Sometimes we despair of the state of the world. What will scientists think of next?
answer: That's precisely it, Ma'am. At this very moment the Germans under Count von Zeppelin, are experimenting with a dirigible --

question: A dirigible? And what, pray, is that?
answer: A rigid balloon, which could fly over London and drop a bomb on Buckingham Palace. It is being developed at the express orders of Kaiser Wilhelm the Second.

question: Nonsense. We refuse to believe that our grandson Willie would do a thing like that.
answer: We have conclusive proof, Ma'am. Our agent in Friedrichshafen, a man named Ibbetson, actually saw the dirigible, and made a drawing of it. Unfortunately, he was apprehended before he could cross the border.

question: Nevertheless, we don't want any part of this beastly invention. Get rid of it! Scuttle it! The sooner the better.
answer: May I point out, Ma'am --

question: Well, Mycroft, it seems we have both been undone by a woman. What a shame.
answer: Not necessarily. If the Germans want that submersible so badly, why don't we give it to them?

question: Give it to them?
answer: Invite them aboard for the final journey -- seven hundred feet -- straight down.

question: And how are you going to arrange that?
answer: I'm rather counting on you to do it. Since you are on such intimate terms with Fraulein von Hoffmanstal. Shall we say goodbye to Her Majesty?

question: Sorry about that. But as long as you're up -- what is the German word for castle? Schloss, isn't it?
answer: I think so.

question: And how would you say under the castle? Unter das Schlss? Or die Schloss?
answer: I don't know. My German isn't that good.

question: Your Trappist friends are out there waiting to hear from you -- it's a chilly morning -- we don't want to keep them standing around too long, do we, Fraulein Hoffmanstal? Come now. It's too late to play cat and mouse.
answer: Unter dem Schloss.

question: Well, it's up to the good monks now. You can consider your part of the mission accomplished, Fraulein Hoffmanstal.
answer: You're all wrong about me. My name isn't Hoffmanstal.

question: It isn't?
answer: It's von Hoffmanstal.

question: I stand corrected.
answer: I suppose once they're in the castle... It must amuse you, Mr. Holmes, Trappists walking into a trap.

question: It's more amusing than that. Once in the castle, they will encounter surprisingly little resistance -- it will take but a small bottle of chloroform to overcome the guards.
answer: You mean you're going to let them have the air-pump?

question: Better than that. We're going to let them have the submersible. They will find it with its engines running, all set to go. I assume they're all expert sailors? And since there is a German battleship cruising off the coast of Scotland, I expect they'll try to sail it out of the lock and rendezvous at sea.
answer: Did you say try to?

question: I would suggest you get your things together. Mycroft will be here to take you into custody.
answer: I never had you fooled for a moment, did I? You knew right from the beginning -- when the cabbie brought me to Baker Street.

question: Let me see -- not quite that soon.
answer: It's so funny. I asked for this assignment, you know. I was scheduled to go to Japan, but I couldn't resist the challenge of coming up against the best. I'm sorry I didn't give you a closer game.

question: Close enough.
answer: You're just being kind. I failed miserably.

question: Holmes! Holmes, I saw it again -- that thing -- it came from the castle -- it's out there
answer: It was out there. Now it's gone.

question: Gone?
answer: Forever. Look for yourself.

question: A bottle of champagne?... and a Bible?...
answer: That's all that's left of H.M.S. Jonah.

question: Fraulein von Hoffmanstal?
answer: Yes, Mr. Holmes. I'm all ready.

question: If there's one thing I like about the Prussians, it's their punctuality.
answer: If there's one thing I dislike about the British, it's their climate. I understand your jails are quite damp -- and your heating facilities totally inadequate.

question: They are. But you're not going to jail. You're going back to Germany.
answer: Germany?

question: You will be conducted to the Swiss-German border, and be exchanged for one of our agents -- a man named Ibbetson.
answer: Thank you.

question: All right, Holmes -- you don't have to explain anything to me, if you don't want to.
answer: I appreciate that, Watson.

question: After all, I'm only your official biographer --
answer: Anyway, I don't think she'd care to have this story spread all over Strand Magazine.

question: The public has a right to know these things. If she's a German spy, why should we concern ourselves about her feelings? If I promised not to write a word about it, would you enlighten me? As your friend -- as your valet --
answer: Quiet. I'm trying to read a personal message.

question: A message? What is she saying?
answer: Auf Wiedersehn.
